form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Kim introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

form.official-title: To direct the Secretary of Education to carry out grant programs to encourage student participation in local government and volunteer service, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Service Starts At Home Act.

section.header: Grants to support internships in local government

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall carry out a program under which the Secretary makes grants, on a competitive basis, to eligible entities to support paid internships within units of local government for secondary school students and students who are qualified undergraduates at institutions of higher education in the State in which the entity is located.

To be considered for a grant under subsection (a), an eligible entity shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.
Each eligible entity that receives a grant under subsection (a) shall use such grant to carry out a program under which the entity—

paragraph.text: identifies appropriate paid internship opportunities within units of local government for secondary school students and students who are undergraduates at institutions of higher education in the State in which the entity is located;
establishes a process for the selection of students to fill such internships;
determines hourly rates of pay and other terms and conditions applicable to such internships; and
pays the costs incurred in providing such internships.

subsection.text: In carrying out the internship program under subsection (c), an eligible entity shall—

paragraph.text: work with institutions of higher education to ensure that the work performed by interns has educational value and meets applicable educational standards; and

seek to provide reasonable employment-related accommodations to interns who have childcare needs, transportation difficulties, or other such challenges, which may include accommodations such as flexible work schedules for interns and allowing interns to telework to the extent determined practicable by the eligibility entity concerned.

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section $50,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2026 through 2030.

subparagraph.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall carry out a program under which the Secretary makes allocations to States, in accordance with subparagraph (B), to carry out the scholarship program under subsection (b).

From the amount appropriated to carry out this section for each fiscal year and not reserved under paragraph (2), each State that has an application approved by the Secretary under subparagraph (C) shall be allocated an amount in proportion to number of students enrolled in the public elementary schools and secondary schools in the State for the previous school year relative to the total number of students enrolled in the public elementary schools and secondary schools for such school year in every State that has an application approved by the Secretary under such subparagraph.

To be eligible to receive an allocation under subparagraph (B), a State shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.

paragraph.text: From the amount appropriated to carry out this section for each fiscal year, the Secretary may reserve not more than 20 percent to carry out the Federal supplemental scholarship program under subsection (c).

Each State that receives an allocation under subsection (a)(2) shall use such allocation to carry out a program under which the State awards scholarships, on a competitive basis, to eligible students who demonstrate a commitment to volunteer service work.
A student who seeks a scholarship under this subsection shall submit an application to the State at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the State may require.
To be eligible to receive a scholarship under this subsection a student shall meet the following criteria:

subparagraph.text: In the case of a first-time applicant for a scholarship under this subsection, the student shall—

subclause.text: in a secondary school and be in the final year of a program of study leading to a regular high school diploma; or
in an institution of higher education; and

clause.text: have completed at least 100 hours of volunteer service work in the preceding school year (or another one-year period determined by the Secretary).

subparagraph.text: In the case of a student who received a scholarship under this subsection for an academic year and is seeking a scholarship for a subsequent academic year, the student shall—

clause.text: be enrolled in an institution of higher education;
be in good academic standing (as determined by the institution); and
have completed at least 100 hours of volunteer service work in the preceding school year (or another one-year period determined by the Secretary).

paragraph.text: Subject to the availability of funds for such purpose, a State that receives an allocation under subsection (a) shall—

subparagraph.text: award a scholarship to each renewal applicant who meets the requirements described in paragraph (3)(B); and
establish a streamlined process under which renewal applicants can apply for such scholarships with minimal documentation required.

paragraph.text: In awarding scholarships under this subsection, a State shall—

subparagraph.text: in accordance with paragraph (4), first award scholarships to renewal applicants described in paragraph (3)(B); and
from any funds remaining after awarding such scholarships, award scholarships to first-time applicants described in paragraph (3)(A).

paragraph.text: A scholarship received by a student under this subsection may be used by such student only to pay the student’s costs of attendance at an institution of higher education.

Each scholarship under this subsection shall be awarded for a period of one academic year. A student may receive a scholarship under this subsection for a total period of not more than 4 academic years.
The amount of each scholarship under this subsection shall be—

subparagraph.text: $1,000, for a student who completed at least 100 hours, but less than 138 hours, of volunteer service work in the preceding school year (or another one-year period determined by the Secretary);
$1,500, for a student who completed at least 138 hours, but less than 175 hours, of volunteer service work in the preceding school year (or another one-year period determined by the Secretary);
$2,000, for a student who completed at least 175 hours, but less than 213 hours, of volunteer service work in such period;
$2,500, for a student who completed at least 213 hours, but less than 250 hours, of volunteer service work in such period; and
$3,000, for a student who completed at least 250 hours of volunteer service work in such period.

paragraph.text: From amounts reserved under subsection (a)(2), the Secretary may carry out a program under which the Secretary awards supplementary funds, on a competitive basis, directly to eligible students for volunteer service work.
The amount of supplementary funds awarded to each student under paragraph (1) shall be determined by the Secretary.
In awarding scholarships under this subsection, the Secretary shall prioritize the award of funds to students who have not received a scholarship under subsection (b).

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section $100,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2026 through 2030.

section.header: Recognition of achievement in community service
section.text: The Secretary shall carry out a program to recognize elementary schools, secondary schools, local educational agencies, and institutions of higher education based on their overall volunteer achievement and contributions to community service.

paragraph.text: The terms elementary school, local educational agency, regular high school diploma, secondary school, Secretary, and State have the meanings given those terms in section 8101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801).
The term cost of attendance has the meaning given that term in section 472 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1087ll).
The term eligible entity means a State or a unit of local government.
The term institution of higher education has the meaning given that term in section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001).
The term unit of local government means—

subparagraph.text: a county, municipality, town, township, village, parish, borough, or other unit of general government below the State level; or
a governing body of an Indian Tribe or Tribal organization.

paragraph.text: The term volunteer service work—

subparagraph.text: means unpaid acts of volunteer service conducted for or on behalf of a government or other nonprofit organization, which may include a community-based organization, faith-based organization, school, national service program, civic or fraternal service organization, local government agency, or other such organization; and

does not include acts of proselytizing, conducting worship services, religious instruction, political lobbying, court ordered service, or service conducted primarily for the benefit of the family of a student eligible for a scholarship under section 3.
